data.text: @latikambourke Getting an extra 12-15 hours a week of their life back and saving 7-9000 dollars a year in expenses.

@latikambourke I live in Western Sydney and all the people I know that wok in the city are doing everything humanely possible short of losing there jobs to go back to the office. There quality of life has improved markedly since being able to work from home.

@latikambourke Hi Latika really enjoy your writings. However personal opinion is that this is because people really prefer working from home are silently protesting against having to go back to office.

@latikambourke Maybe it is not damage so much as a realignment of working practices to better reflect the realities of modern communications. The pandemic may have been the trigger but if both employers (less office rent) and employees (can have a job and a life) are happy could be a win/win.
@latikambourke Ah the property council PR machine, “bringing cities back to life”.
@latikambourke Says someone who lives in Britain.
@sloane_london Victoria only lifted work from home orders last week, similarly with indoor mask wearing.

@latikambourke The fact that this is seen as a concern and not the almost 1000 Britons dying each week and the millions with Long COVID really says something. No doubt examples of pure apathy and complete lack of priorities will be something for the history books.
@latikambourke Maybe everyone’s living in fear. Or maybe they just realised that heading into congested CBDs every day sucked and they can work better from home.

@latikambourke Latika, with all respect, why are you such a Ripster? You’ve got >100 people dying each day in the UK. That’s not okay and shouldn’t be normalised under any circumstances. Lockdowns saved untold numbers of lives and the fact that this is seen as problematic is quite strange.
